results.title: Child's toy tin magic lantern with candle projection
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description:
Magic Lantern with removable chimney and internal wooden block.

The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit was donated by Edwin Schefferle - “When Edwin was about 10 years of age, he acquired a Magic Lantern Outfit from his Grandma. This fired his imagination; he would make images with ink on strips of cellophane and project these through the Magic Lantern by means of a candle onto an old sheet draped on the wall. The result was disappointing but encouraging. The one candle did not provide sufficient light especially during daylight. Little did he realise that he had opened a door on a world of projecting images on large screens. He had abandoned merry-go-rounds and wind mills but this was different. He never let go of his Magic Lantern; it could well have been dubbed his lighthouse showing him the way to go. What happened to his Magic Lantern? After his death in 2014 it was found among his belongings and was donated to the Australian Centre for Moving Image (ACMI) which superseded the State Film Centre, where Edwin spent most of his working life.” (text from book - ‘Life with a Purpose, Conversations with Edwin James Schefferle - Scheff’)

results.title: Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector
results.brief_description:
The Pettibone Mfg. Co. (Cincinatti, Ohio) patented this striking magic lantern with revolving disc in 1888 for use primarily in fraternal society lodges.
The revolving disc that holds 10 small circular discs of glass with brightly coloured pictures gave this version its popular nickname of the “peacock”, because of the resemblance to a peacock that has fanned out its tail.
The black triangle piece holds the revolving disc and has a click to lock the frames to prevent them from moving when they are projected.

-Object does not have a flue
-Lens can be extended 1.8 cm
-Internal condenser lens is a later addition and does not fit well

Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) Magic Lantern Projector - Ebay purchase

Original listing: https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/352469927305
From listing:
This is one that has been sitting collecting dust for many years, an 1880s dated Pettibone Paragon (Peacock) magic lantern projector. It has the stenciled triangle with the 1888 date as well as “Paragon” on the front which both sides have wear but these are actually harder to find with the painted stenciled lettering on it. The reel is full but a couple of the slides are broken but still for display purposes on a shelf looks alright. The body is the blued steel look which depending on the lighting either shows the blue look or more towards black if the lighting is bad. The front lens does extend with the turn knob and also retracts. The front lens & condensor lens are good just need a proper cleaning like the rest of this. The wood base does have some scratches which if someone were to use a stain pen you could probably fix those spots up pretty quick. Overall “G” good condition as seen with wear. The rails on this one are a brass color which the later models were just nickel plated. In back is no burner which it had been electrified so that old unit was thrown away.

results.title: Phar Lap: the people's champion [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Eddie Carnana, Michael Dickinson, Rhett Kirkwood and Hall of Fame Corporation
results.brief_description: The People’s champion, Phar Lap, is an icon of Australia’s past. This video contains previously unseen footage of the greatest thoroughbred there ever was. Footage is contributed featuring Tommy Woodcock, Harry Telford and American businessman David Davis, as well as including the amazing story of Cups King Bart Cummings, whose record 10 Melbourne Cup triumphs is equally worthy of praise.

results.title: Driller killer [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Abel Ferrara, Rochelle Weisberg, D Metrov and Navaron Productions
results.brief_description: In retrospect, the notoriety surrounding Abel Ferrara’s early feature might have had more to do with the film’s provocative title than the content itself. At the time however, “Driller killer” became the scapegoat for the 80s ‘Video nasty’ hysteria, which saw the film unfairly lumped with other exploitation films such as “I spit on your grave” and “Blood sucking freaks.” Subsequently the film was either banned outright in some countries (including the UK), or severely modified for many years. Over the years however the film has enjoyed a renaissance of sorts mainly due to Ferrara’s growing reputation as a filmmaker. The grungy low budget look and punk sensibility of “Driller killer” is a perfect match for this story of a New York artist (played by Ferrara under the pseudonym Jimmy Laine) gradually driven insane. His only recourse from the insistent noise and chaos of the New York streets is to power tool anyone that gets in his way. Ferrara’s films, full of spiritual torment and redemption through bloodletting have seen the director compared to fellow New Yorker Martin Scorsese. With “Driller killer” however, its spiritual doppelganger ends up being Roman Polanski’s disturbing tale of madness, “Repulsion.” There’s even a perverse homage to the skinned rabbit from that film. Cast includes: Carolyn Marz, Baybi Day and Harry Schultz.

results.title: Drifting in Antarctica
results.brief_description: Alice, a profoundly deaf Zoologist, tells of her experience as a volunteer seabird observer on a working icebreaker in Antarctica. Featuring excerpts from “The rime of the ancient mariner” by Samuel Taylor Coleridge. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.

results.title: Petroleum's progress
results.creator_credit: Tom Fletcher, Michael Scott, Jerry Krepakevich and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Archival footage and commercials provide a history of oil and oil by-products, and of the creation of the petro-chemical industry. Man has developed a frightening dependence on oil. Not only do oil by-products keep him warm and mobile, they help to feed, clean, clothe and entertain him. The film makes the point that there is yet no substitute for oil.

results.title: Petersen
results.brief_description: Petersen is an electrician and former football star who yearns to be a teacher, so he attends university. But it’s the female professors, students, and all the women he comes in contact with who learn a thing or two from him. Stars Jack Thompson, Jacki Weaver and Wendy Hughes.

results.title: Peter Yeldham's Captain James Cook. Part two
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Gordon Clark, Ray Alchin, ABC-TV (Australia) and Revcom Television
results.brief_description: In the late 1700’s King George 111 of England orders an ambitious expedition to the Pacific Ocean to observe an eclipse of the sun and to seek the mythical Southern Continent. James Cook (Keith Michell), a relatively unknown petty officer, is controversially appointed as commander, choosing an unlikely collier to carry him and his men into dangerous and unknown waters. After sailing to Tahiti, where the eclipse proves disappointing, Cook proceeds to chart the coasts of New Zealand and Australia beginning a glorious adventure spanning the oceans of the world. Part two concludes the saga of one of history’s great ocean explorers. Cast includes Keith Michell, Carol Drinkwater, Fernando Ray and Jaques Penot. Based on the novel by Peter Yeldham.

results.title: Peter Weir: short film collection
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Film Australia and ScreenSound Australia
results.brief_description: Three to go: Michael: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Michael has to make decisions in the complex but permissive world of today. His friends have followed a relatively straight and narrow path of conformity. Michael has more or less taken this course, but knows that other ways exist. He is prepared to listen to the prophets of change and revolution and is taken on an excursion into the world of the young radical. In which world does Michael belong?. Features Grahame Bond. Homesdale: Mr. Malfry is having his first vacation at Homesdale - an expensive, private guest house on a remote island near Sydney. The guests are encouraged to live out their fantasies, and have accustomed themselves to the atmosphere with ease. Mr. Malfry emerges as the odd man out and his efforts to mix in are unsuccessful, until a solution occurs to him. Treading a perilous line between horror and farce, “Homesdale” deliberately eschews plot and character development. Isolation, eccentricity and mad authority are the ingredients for this loosely woven depiction of life in a mysterious sanatorium. Three directions in Australian Pop Music: Australian Colour Diary 43: Three songs performed by three Australian artists from 1971; Wendy Saddington and Teardrop; The Captain Matchbox Whoopee Band and Indelible Murtceps. Long hair, mime and psychodelic lighting are part of the experience! Incredible Floridas: This is composer Richard Meale’s homage to the French poet, Arthur Rimbaud. Scored for woodwind, percussion and string instruments, it was written for the “Fires of London” and their conductor, Peter Maxwell Davies, and premiered in London in 1971 to an enthusiastic reception. Richard Meale is a leader in contemporary music in Australia. Released on DVD by Umbrella Entertainment and The AV Channel. Also available on VHS/16mm [010905], [300809], [005261].
